results.title: Pieces in the Puzzle
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Christine Sammers
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Warriors”.
A program on women in war. Six Australian women discuss their experiences in, and consequent attitudes to, war. The first half of the program focuses on World War II and features Polish ex-Army officer, Anna Kosinski, who was imprisoned by the Nazis in Warsaw; Ruby Boye-Jones, ex-WRAN coast-watcher on the Solomon Islands and Gwen Campbell, ex-WAAF Wing Commander who served in Australia. The second half of the program turns to three women in war-torn Third World countries - ABC political journalist, Mary Delahunty, in El Salvador in 1982; political filmmaker, Fionna Douglas, in Eritrea and Mozambique; and horticulturalist, Ruth Beilin, working on an agricultural development project in Mozambique.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Christine Sammers

results.title: Piece of cake
results.brief_description: A dramatisation of two old friends who give each other support in dealing with the loneliness of old age. In the film, one of the two old men is expecting his married daughter back from overseas for Christmas and plans a splendid dinner. Unable to raise credit at the local shop to buy a goose, he persuades his reluctant old friend to help him “catch” one.

results.title: Piece By Piece (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Focus on the pre-school teacher as evacuator and a decision-maker whose actions influence the quality of the experiences that children have within the educational program. What types of activity can be deemed part of evaluating, what criteria are important when evaluating and why evaluate, are some of the questions discussed

results.title: Picturesque Tasmania
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept of Commerce. Cinema Branch and G Gamon
results.brief_description: Produced by the Cinema Branch, Australian Department of Commerce. A driving tour of Tasmania from Hobart along the western, northern, eastern and southern coasts focussing on the natural scenery. A number of towns and their various industries can also be seen such as trout hatcheries, the Mt Lyell mine, hops and apple growing. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Pictures that post
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Australia Post, Don Murray and Paul Woolston-Smith
results.brief_description: The background to ideas chosen for stamp issues, the source of ideas and how they come to end up on the top righthand corner of most of the three thousand million articles handled each year by Australia Post - that’s the story of this film. Whilst a dozen or more stamp series are issued each year, none has been more successful than the series featuring Australian roses. Both the rose grower and artist, Brian Clinton, feature in the film as well as Deanne Head, one of the three child artists whose designs have been selected for the 1983 Christmas issue. In the film, the stamp designs and the scenes that have inspired them make an informative and entertaining collage.

results.title: Pictures teach at Penfield
results.brief_description: Illustrates the role of audio-visual materials in elementary and secondary education by dramatising the teaching methods used at Penfield, New York, Central School District, where films, slides and film-strips are integral parts of the curriculum. The story centres around the reactions of two students, brother and sister, to audio-visual instruction.

results.title: Pictures out of my life
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Canada Dept of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, Wolf Koenig and Bozenna Heczko
results.brief_description: The drawings and recollections of Inuit artist Pitseolak, from the book of the same title written by Dorothy Eber. Now in her seventies, Pitseolak is one of the most famous of the graphic artists of the Cape Dorset (Baffin Island) artists’ colony and cooperative. Her coloured pencil and felt-pen drawings vividly illustrate her memories of past life in the Arctic, and of the birds, animals and spirits that figured so large in the daily life of the Inuit.

results.title: Pictures of the invisible
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International, Thirteen, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Lois Bianchi, Mark Anderson and Carol Stowe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
In 1858 the picture of the world was transformed by the Frenchman Nadar who combined the new technologies of hot air ballooning and photography to produce the first reproducible “bird’s eye” view of the world. The technique of aerial photography has had extensive military use, but it has also enabled previously unmapped areas, such as the Himalayas and the Amazon to be accurately mapped. Now aerial mapping has been extended to photography from satellites and computer imaging of data, a process also used to convert radar “photography” of what lies beneath the surface of land and sea into a comprehensible form. Narrated by Patrick Stewart.

results.title: Pictures of France: Roussillon
results.creator_credit: French Government Tourist Office and Max Sautet
results.brief_description: A rugged landscape compounded of vineyards, rocks and mountains forms the province of Rousillon. At Perpignon, carnival festivities with dancing, masks and fireworks, culminate in a solemn Easter procession through the streets. Traces of various cultural influences remain today in the colour of the bullring and the quaint abbey town with rock-hewn walls and narrow streets. This rich variety of life and architecture makes a painters’ paradise, as ancient traditions are kept alive.

results.title: Pictures beneath the cobblestones: July 28th, 1830 Liberty leading the people(1830)
results.creator_credit: La Sept, FR3, Delta Image, Les Films d'ici and Alain Jaubert
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Delacroix’s picture “Liberty leading the people” was painted in 1830 and depicts the uprising in Paris which resulted in the installation of Louis Philipe as king. This program looks in detail at the painting itself, the techniques that Delacroix used, outside influences on his art, the symbolism he uses and the reception his painting received, as well as looking briefly at the events which inspired the work.
results.title_for_label: Pictures beneath the cobblestones: July 28th, 1830 Liberty leading the people(1830)
